title: Helvetica Ligatures
content:
I was curius what helvetica would look like with some ligatures, and couldn’t find any examples, so I decided to make my own. I made two versions, one is more linear based on the forms of the t and the second is more curvy based on the top of the s. I understand that this is purely ornamental, but I wanted to do some experimenting.

[http://www.typeandglyph.com/2009/01/deservedly-rare/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150311184224/http:/www.typeandglyph.com/2009/01/deservedly-rare/ "http://www.typeandglyph.com/2009/01/deservedly-rare/")

Has anyone else seen any good examples of helvetica ligatures.
author: grntwlkr

comments.content: I think the first version is very interesting but the second one is keeping with the typeface better. Cool stuff.
Helvetica has ligatures?! Hahah..this is a good idea, though I'm not fond of Helvetica.

Usually, ligatures had not worked well with sans faces, but yours is a cool try, even when it's heretic.  
I agree with Nachos on preserving font consistence.  
Anyway, I find some quirk effect in the encounters.  
Probably they needs to be softened.
